speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me what's been going on that's causing you to feel so agitated and confused? Have you experienced any recent head injuries or trauma? How long have you been feeling this way?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know, doc... everything just seems to be piling up, you know? I've been studying for finals nonstop and it's like my brain is gonna explode. And yeah, I did have a pretty intense workout at the gym earlier, but that usually helps me clear my head, not makes me feel worse.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe what you mean by 'everything piling up' - are you experiencing any specific thoughts or feelings that are overwhelming you? Have you noticed any changes in your body temperature, heart rate, or sweating since your workout?

speaker: Patient
text: It's just... I don't know, everything feels so intense and frustrating all the time. I get these overwhelming urges to just lash out or do something physical, like yell or lift weights. And yeah, I've been sweating a lot, even when I'm not working out - it's pretty annoying, doc.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or sleep patterns recently? Are you experiencing any tremors, muscle weakness, or difficulty controlling your movements? REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: WBC: Normal, Hemoglobin: Normal, Platelets: Normal

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these intense urges to lash out or do something physical - are they triggered by specific situations or people, or do they seem to come out of nowhere? Have you experienced any changes in your vision, such as blurred vision or sensitivity to light? REQUEST TEST: Electrolyte Panel.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your bowel movements or urinary habits recently, such as diarrhea, constipation, or frequent urination? Have you been experiencing any headaches or migraines that could be contributing to your altered mental status? REQUEST TEST: Thyroid Function Tests.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any recent travel or exposure to anyone who's been ill, and have you noticed any changes in your sense of smell or taste? Have you been taking any new medications or supplements that could be contributing to your symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Toxicology Screen.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Amphetamines: Positive, Cocaine: Negative, Opiates: Negative, Benzodiazepines: Negative, Cannabinoids: Negative

speaker: Doctor
text: It looks like the toxicology screen came back positive for amphetamines - can you tell me if you've been taking any prescription medications or using any recreational substances that could contain amphetamines? Have you noticed any changes in your behavior or mood when you're not using these substances? REQUEST TEST: Urine Culture.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your use of amphetamines - are you taking them as prescribed by a doctor or are you using them recreationally? Have you noticed any correlation between your amphetamine use and these intense urges to lash out or do something physical? REQUEST TEST: Liver Function Tests.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me how long you've been using amphetamines and in what quantities, and have you experienced any withdrawal symptoms when you haven't taken them? Have you considered seeking help for what appears to be a substance use issue that may be contributing to your aggressive behavior and altered mental status? REQUEST TEST: Brain MRI.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your behavior or mood when you haven't taken amphetamines for a period of time, such as feeling irritable or anxious? Have you experienced any seizures or tremors since using amphetamines? REQUEST TEST: EEG.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever experienced a period of time where you didn't use amphetamines for an extended period, and if so, how did you feel during that time? Did you experience any cravings or withdrawal symptoms, such as headaches or fatigue? REQUEST TEST: Psychological Evaluation.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Irritability, agitation, rapid speech, aggressive behavior, notably dilated pupils; patient exhibits diaphoresis and tachycardia, with a heart rate of 120/min and blood pressure of 137/98 mmHg, indicating potential symptoms of amphetamine use disorder.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like the psychological evaluation has revealed some concerning symptoms consistent with amphetamine use disorder. Can you tell me if you've ever tried to cut down or control your amphetamine use, but found it difficult to do so? Have you continued to use amphetamines despite noticing negative effects on your daily life and relationships? REQUEST TEST: Comprehensive Metabolic Panel.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Sodium: Normal, Potassium: Normal, Creatinine: Normal, Blood_Glucose: Normal

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like the comprehensive metabolic panel results are all within normal ranges. Can you tell me if you've ever experienced any episodes of psychosis or hallucinations while using amphetamines, and have you noticed any changes in your relationships with friends and family since starting to use them? Have you considered seeking help from a substance abuse counselor or therapist to address your amphetamine use? REQUEST TEST: ECG.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever felt like you need to take increasingly larger doses of amphetamines to achieve the same effects, or if you've experienced any withdrawal symptoms when you haven't taken them for a while? Have you considered the possibility that your amphetamine use may be contributing to your aggressive behavior and altered mental status? REQUEST TEST: Blood_Gas_Analysis.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like all the test results are coming back normal, which suggests that your symptoms may be primarily related to your amphetamine use. Can you tell me if you're willing to consider seeking help for your substance use disorder and entering a treatment program to address your addiction? Have you thought about how your life might change if you were able to stop using amphetamines and manage your stress and anxiety in healthier ways? REQUEST TEST: Urine Drug Screen to confirm the presence of amphetamines.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Amphetamines: Positive, Cocaine: Negative, Opiates: Negative, Benzodiazepines: Negative, Cannabinoids: Negative

speaker: Doctor
text: It looks like the urine drug screen has confirmed the presence of amphetamines in your system. Can you tell me if you're ready to acknowledge that your amphetamine use is a problem and take steps to address it, such as seeking counseling or entering a rehabilitation program? Have you thought about how quitting amphetamines might improve your overall health and wellbeing? REQUEST TEST: None, I think we have enough information to move forward with a diagnosis.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Temperature: 101°F (38.3°C), Blood Pressure: 137/98 mmHg, Heart Rate: 120/min, Respiratory Rate: 23/min, Oxygen Saturation: 99% on room air; Patient exhibits irritability, agitation, rapid speech, aggressive behavior, notably dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and tachycardia, consistent with symptoms of amphetamine use disorder.

speaker: Doctor
text: It's clear that your amphetamine use is having a significant impact on your physical and mental health. Can you tell me if you're experiencing any feelings of paranoia or anxiety right now, and have you considered the possibility that your aggressive behavior and altered mental status may be related to amphetamine-induced psychosis? Have you ever had any episodes of severe agitation or aggression that required medical attention or intervention from others?

speaker: Patient
text: Doc, I... I don't know what's going on with me, okay? I just feel like I'm losing control and everything is spinning out of control. Yeah, I've been feeling really paranoid and anxious, like someone's watching me or something. And yeah, I've had episodes where I just snap and lose it, but I never thought it was that big of a deal... I just figured I was stressed or tired or something. But now that you mention it, maybe it is related to... you know, the stuff I've been taking.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're starting to recognize the potential connection between your amphetamine use and your aggressive behavior, as well as your feelings of paranoia and anxiety. Can you tell me if you're willing to work with me to develop a plan to safely detox from amphetamines and address any underlying mental health issues that may be contributing to your symptoms? Have you considered the possibility that you may need to be admitted to a hospital or treatment facility to ensure your safety and the safety of those around you? REQUEST TEST: None, I think we've gathered enough information.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital Signs - Temperature: 101°F (38.3°C), Blood Pressure: 137/98 mmHg, Heart Rate: 120/min, Respiratory Rate: 23/min, Oxygen Saturation: 99% on room air; General Examination - Appearance: Irritable young man, Skin: Notable diaphoresis; Cardiopulmonary Examination - Heart: Tachycardia, Lungs: Bilateral clear breath sounds; Neurological Examination - Pupils: Notably dilated, Mental Status: Rapid speech, aggressive; Diagnostic Impression - Amphetamine Use Disorder.

speaker: Doctor
text: It's clear that your amphetamine use has led to a state of acute intoxication, and I'm concerned about the potential for further escalation of your symptoms. Can you tell me if you're experiencing any suicidal or homicidal ideation at this time? Have you considered the possibility that you may need to be hospitalized to ensure your safety and the safety of those around you?

speaker: Patient
text: Doc, I... I don't know, okay? I'm just really scared and I feel like I'm losing my mind. I haven't thought about hurting myself or anyone else, but I do feel like I'm on the edge of something and I don't know how to pull back. Hospitalization sounds crazy, but at the same time, I don't know what else to do - I just want to feel normal again. Can you help me with that?

speaker: Doctor
text:
DIAGNOSIS READY: Amphetamine Use Disorder with acute intoxication. 

The consensus among the doctors is clear, with all of them agreeing that the patient's symptoms, such as irritability, agitation, rapid speech, aggressive behavior, dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and tachycardia, along with the positive toxicology screen for amphetamines and the patient's admission to using these substances, point towards Amphetamine Use Disorder. The mention of Cholecystitis seems unrelated to the discussion provided by the doctors.
